bibl.title: Letter from Henry Rose Carter to W. Byam, February 12, 1919

div1.p: Carter is sending Byam a paper on yellow fever for publication. Carter intends to consult with Noguchi to see if he may quote the results of latest research.

div1.head: Letter from Henry Rose Carter to W. Byam, February 12, 1919
div1.opener:
Yellow Fever
Oxford Press
/LC
February 12, 1919.
Major W..Byam, R. A. M. C.,
12 Heath Mansions,
Hampstead,
London, N. W. S. England.
Dear Major Byam:
div1.p:
Your letter without date, but posted January 4th., just
received on my return from New Orleans.

1/ There will be no plates required for my paper, unless
two pulse and temperature charts are so considered.

2/ I am engaged in reorganizing our Malaria Control Work
on a peace basis--a rather heavy work--and hence am much pressed
for time. Fortunately, I began the paper on December 26th., tak-
ing a chance of doing unnecessary work, and it is complete in the
rough. Were not this so, I would not be able to complete it in
time.

3/ This is a rather unfortunate time for a paper on yellow
fever, as Noguchi, of the Rockefeller Institute, who has been
working in Guayaquil, has an organism, which he thinks is causi-
tive of yellow fever. I am going to New York to his laboratory
in a couple of days to (1) see what he has and (2) find out to
what extent I may quote him. In another year this matter of
-2-
laboratory diagnosis might have been settled.

4/ I will, of course, keep the paper to the number of
words allowed, although 20% or 25% more would have made it 100%
more valuable and much easier to read. I will shorten it, but
doubt if have time to arrange it to strictly conform to your
scheme, as--as I have already said--I am extremely pressed.
div1.closer:
Very truly yours, Assistant Surgeon General H. R. Carter,
U. S. Marine Hospital,
Baltimore, Md., U. S. A.
In regard to the particulars you request about myself. I
trust that the following, which are the ones specially applicable
to the present article, will be sufficient:
H. R. Carter,
Assistant Surgeon General,
U. S. Public Health Service,
Late
Director of Hospitals and
Chief Quarantine Officer,
Canal Zone,
Isthmus of Panama,
Chief Quarantine Officer,
Island of Cuba.
Member of various Medical and Scientific Societies
Very truly yours,

div1.opener:
/LC
February 12, 1919.
Major W. Byam, R. A. M. C.,
12, Heath Mansions,
Hampstead,
London, N. W. 3, England.
Dear Major Byam:
div1.p:
I should have added to my note just mailed, that I do not
care for any compensation for the paper that I will send you.
I will be glad if you will turn it over to any British War Re-
lief that seems to you to be suitable.

I am sorry, however, not to be able to send you the paper
as already written. It loses much in value and all individuality
from the close trimming it will have to get.
div1.closer:
Very truly yours, Assistant Surgeon General H. R. Carter,
U. S. Marine Hospital,
Baltimore, Md., U. S. A.
